text: This thread needed to be a blog post, so I wrote it: continued use of personal email & encrypted messaging in the WhiteHouse exposes accountability hole in public records laws: https://e-pluribusunum.org/2019/03/22/continued-use-of-personal-email-and-encrypted-messaging-in-white-house-exposes-accountability-hole-in-public-records-laws/ … This is a crisis of ethics in government, not technology.
author: digiphile

text: As @NatlSecCnslrs highlights, what we face is a crisis not of tech but of ethics. At its core, the Presidential Records Act is an honor system: https://www.justsecurity.org/63348/trump-and-the-demise-of-the-presidential-records-honor-system/ … Congress assumed a @POTUS would voluntarily comply with the law. Again, Trump's exposed an accountability hole.
author: digiphile

text: An #opengov irony: in an era when we’ve never had so much instant access to information or ability to save it, there's also an unprecedented number of free, easy-to-use private messaging apps that enable officials to hide secrets.  https://abc6onyourside.com/news/nation-world/new-technology-presents-new-threats-to-transparency-in-government …
author: digiphile

text: As with the use of personal devices & private systems, this is a widespread problem across every level of government, with both Democrats & Republicans, for both good & bad reasons. Cf. @EricGreitens: https://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article188405944.html …
author: digiphile

text: The key issue is not encryption, per se, but whether any official government business is being conducted or not. If so, then messages should be memorialized. Screenshots work, but they're suboptimal & depend on an official/civil servant's always archiving. https://www.nextgov.com/it-modernization/2017/02/how-feds-can-use-encrypted-appswithout-breaking-law/135132/ …
author: digiphile

text: There's nothing wrong with government officials using encrypted/ephemeral apps for personal communication: https://freedom-to-tinker.com/2017/02/27/on-encryption-apps-in-the-white-house/ … In fact, it's good risk modeling for @WhiteHouse officials, given that  their devices & comms will be targeted by various foreign intel  services
author: digiphile

text:
This is NOT a new issue. In February 2017, @USNatArchives issued guidance on PRA & FRA: https://www.archives.gov/news/fra-pra-guidance …
after news outlets reported new @WhiteHouse officials were using encrypted, ephemeral apps: https://www.zdnet.com/article/trump-aides-use-of-encrypted-messaging-verges-on-violating-records-law/ … Signal & Confide are made for shadows, not sunshine
author: digiphile

text: NO. If a given encrypted or ephemeral app does not have archiving built in, public servants should not use it for public business, much less in the @WhiteHouse.  @WhatsApp isn't approved by @USGSA: https://digital.gov/resources/negotiated-terms-of-service-agreements/ … Use secure official systems that memorialize messaging.
author: digiphile

text:

text: The @USDS can’t fix what ails US government, any more than @18F or @InnovFellows can — or a similar service would do in Congress. They can & will help, inspire, improve, & heal, but not solve. We need people to restore good government in DC, armed with knowledge & the rule of law
author: digiphile

text: The @USDS staff I’ve met are extraordinary. Talented, thoughtful, committed, generous. Patriots, who stayed in service or joined in hopes of helping tens of millions of Americans at scale, despite the context we are are living through. They’re far from alone in our government.
author: digiphile

I agree. Here's how I think that would work in practice:
No lies repeated in headlines. State established facts first. https://e-pluribusunum.org/2018/07/21/in-search-of-a-vaccine-for-a-disinformation-virus/ …
No false claims unchecked in article body. 
No live broadcasts of rallies.
No retweets/quote tweets without adding context & verification

text: I went to Congress for a hearing on the Freedom of Information Act during #SunshineWeek. Here’s a thread on what I heard - and didn’t - during more than two hours of questioning:
author: digiphile

text:
Sarbanes puts a statement by @Public_Citizen into the record, & adjourned. On a bunch counts, this was disappointing.
Nothing on deleted CAP goal. Nothing on missing FOIA policy from @FOIAPost. Nothing on #OpenGovAct. Nothing on @TheJusticeDept defense of FOIA.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @DWStweets, who asks about why a new process for @FOIA was been implemented for disclosure under following @SecretaryZinke's departure. Any other reason to add, other than protecting him?
Acting DCFO: May be other reasons.
DWS: Doesn't pass smell test.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Sidenote: It's disappointing that neither Members or witnesses made any reference to the #OpenGovData Act, @USDataGovt https://e-pluribusunum.org/2019/01/15/president-trump-signs-historic-open-government-data-bill-into-law/ … Most of all, no one is asking @FOIAPost about missing FOIA policy: https://federalnewsnetwork.com/open-datatransparency/2017/11/open-government-advocates-push-for-finalization-of-release-to-one-release-to-all-policy/ … #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
YES! @PeterWelch notes Kwoka's research showing companies buying records under FOIA: https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2685402 … 
Why aren't SEC & agencies disclosing that information?
How does it serve the public?
@FOIAPost: public is best served by posting info for free on websites.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text:
Sarbanes: What's the number?
@Interior DCFO: There is none. We calculate monthly processing capability.
Sarbanes: Not sure that's in the spirit of FOIA.
He continues line of questioning.
Interior DCFO says this proposed rule promotes spirit. 
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Now the #FOIA hearing in Congress is almost empty. Most members asked their questions for 5 minutes  and left. If you haven’t been to DC, this is what hearing usually look like. It’s disappointing to see it during #SunshineWeek.
author: digiphile

text:
Now @RepSarbanes, who also brings up proposed @Interior rule that would restrict FOIA, contradicting the intent of Congress when it passed 2016 reform. What's the monthly limit on requests?
Interior: Effort to "equalize provision of records" to all FOIA requestors 
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text:
Now @RepGrothman: How many requests from http://FOIA.gov ?
OIP: 9,000. It was built with user-feedback. (Disclosure: I was part of that feedback throughout.) Default position for agencies with automated FOIA is they'll need to be interoperable with an API.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Interior: My understanding was that rule was provided to @FedRegister at beginning of shutdown. 
Tlaib: Just looks bad: can't accept new FOIA requests but issuing new rules. @Interior should be using resources to advance transparency. #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Tlaib: Even though @Interior claimed couldn't accept FOIA requests during shutdown, issued new proposed rule during shutdown. Because of shutdown, comments couldn't be reviewed. Was 3 days enough to review comments? Why did Interior rush rule? #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @RepRashida asks why @Interior wasn't able to accept FOIA requests during shutdown. Was there a written document?
DCFO: Unaware of document. FOIAonline requires staffing; no funds to provide. 
Tlaib: @USEEOC website accepted FOIA during shutdown.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Sidenote: statistics on FOIA are available on https://www.foia.gov/  & from @FOIAPost. As witnesses note, this is all data that's available. Asking them about stats & changes in numbers is not particularly effective oversight of #opengov right now. #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text:
Hill: are requestors being given opportunity to simplify FOIA requests? Is that happening?
@EPA says yes.
Hill: Federal judge ruled in December that FOIA couldn't slowwalk FOIA.
How many staff hired?
EPA: Office of administrator has hired 5 staff. Also a "Tiger team" for review.
author: digiphile

text:
Now @RepKatieHill references @EPICprivacy, & asks @EPA if still using "First in, First Out." (NB: @POGOblog highlighted FOIA delays: https://psmag.com/environment/watchdog-group-highlights-epa-delayed-foia-responses …)
Hill asks if multi-track process not being followed?
EPA: My understanding it's been consistently followed
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @MichaelJCloud, who brought a visual aid of FOIA requests received, now asking whether 1000 pages is a "vast quantity." 

Getting into the weeds of stats, but not whether the responses are of high quality or responsive. #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Cummings: every public official should be making & preserving a transparent record of their meetings so that the American people know who is influencing policies. (Well, yeah: https://sunlightfoundation.com/2017/10/17/how-transparency-can-help-the-public-trust-federal-stewardship-of-taxpayer-dollars/ …) #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Cummings: Whose records do you search to respond to requests about acting secretary's calendars?
Interior: haven't performed that task. Assume electronic calendars by staff. 
Context: https://www.wsls.com/news/politics/congress-wants-to-see-acting-interior-secretarys-calendar …
#SunshineWeek #OpenGov #FOIA
author: digiphile

text:
Cummings: possible calendars deleted?
Interior: Understand solicitor's office working with records office to determine what's occurred & is consistent. 
Cummings: any employee tasked with recreating calendar with Google Calendar? or to stop?
Not to my knowledge.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @RepCummings; concerns about meetings held by @DOIDepSec. Does acting secretary not keep a calendar?
@Interior: Was not involved in advice. There are calendars. We post online.
Well. Yes, & no: https://www.doi.gov/foia/os/secretarial-calendars …
#SunshineWeek #openGov
author: digiphile

text:
How's 2018 look?
OIP: Prediction is another increase in incoming. Hopeful will have increase in processing. Predicting backlog might increase.
Jordan: More than 40,000?
OIP: Not sure. Have 90+ agencies. In next months or so. (That's why no @AP #SunshineWeek story on censorship)
author: digiphile

text:
Now @jim_jordan: How many FOIA requests govt-wide, in 2017?
OIP: 800,000+ 
How much more?
OIP: You'll see a steady incline from 2009.
What about backlog?
OIP: In FY2017, backlog down 3%, primarily due to @DHSgov. Mostly due to big agencies: DOJ, Justice, State, NARA
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @StaceyPlaskett asks about secrecy of OLC opinions. Cf @POGOblog: https://www.pogo.org/analysis/2018/09/office-of-legal-counsel-publishes-new-secret-law-opinions/ …
@FOIAPost: I understand the public is interested in OLC memoranda.
Plaskett: would it surprise you that over 200 haven't been released?
No. #sunshineweek #opengov
author: digiphile

text: Then @RepClayHiggins makes a statement suggesting that FOIA has "perhaps been weaponized against our current president." File this under oversight being "presidential harassment." Journalists & watchdogs use FOIA as it was intended. #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @RepClayHiggins asks about gov't-wide statistics. @FOIAPost says in 2017, government reduced its backlog. Agencies making good-faith effort to process overwhelming requests.
What's unsaid: that may mean disclosing wholly redacted documents & partial disclosures. #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text:
Has @TheJusticeDept made every report available on its website? ask @AOC.
OIP: Coding.
@EPA posted report yesterday. When did you provide it to DoJ?
EPA: Don't recall.
What is @TheJusticeDept doing to make FOIA reports accessible to public in a timely manner?
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text:
In response to @RepGosar, @Interior DCFO says increase in lawsuits in response to non-responses. Says that's glorified FOIA processing under the auspices of the court.
Gosar asks if way to look at docs as they come in for better triage? Monitoring at discovery? #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Now @RepGosar references the panoply of well-worn Obama-era "transparency" crusades pushed during @DarrellIssa's term, like Benghazi, Fast & Furious, & asks his colleagues to help @JudicialWatch.  #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Rouda says we're 2 years into administration, 1700 FOIA requests haven't been met, notes hires haven't been made to help. Is there a special team that is reviewing these requests?
@EPA: Yes, in my office since 2013.
Do you personally review them? Yes.
#SunshineWeek #opengov
author: digiphile

text:
In answer to @HarleyRouda's question about whether @EPA's FOIA problems are about policy, resources or process, answer boils down to all of the above.
Do you support the @POTUS' 31% proposed cut to the @EPA?
Will work with Congress on budget.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: The Department of the @Interior is not concerned about who the #FOIA requests are coming from, says its DCFO, in response to @KYComer. (She's testifying under oath: if it turns out Interior officials have been flagging certain responses, that's… problematic.) #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Part of its articulated role is not to just to make requests but to educate the public. A lot of folks may be getting passed through to agency systems.
author: digiphile

text:
Our statutory mission is to "encourage compliance with the FOIA," says the @FOIAPost director. Lynch isn't satisfied.
Lynch says @CREWcrew is now seeking these docs. In response, the agencies have all gone silent.
OIP: our guidance to agencies is to acknowledge
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text: Now @RepStephenLynch asks about whistleblowers regarding transfer of nuclear tech to Saudi Arabia & referencing @oversightdems report on it: https://oversight.house.gov/sites/democrats.oversight.house.gov/files/Trump%20Saudi%20Nuclear%20Report%20-%202-19-2019.pdf …
author: digiphile

text:
Answer from @EPA: Have seen increase. Seen requests concentrated more in the office of the administrator. Haven't broken down types of requestors. 
Complex requests? Have seen increase in complexity over time, particularly in the last couple years.
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Now @congressmanhice asks how many people work on FOIA at @EPA & if offices are adequate. @EPA acknowledges substantial backlog. "Have plans" to deal with it. Looking at "ways of centralizing program."
What kinds of requests coming in? Reporters? Public? Advocacy? #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile
digiphile

text: Following @energy's move to reduce information about public servants from public access, @FERC has now done the same. During #SunshineWeek.
author: digiphile

text:
Now @RepMaloney talks about @Interior's proposed #FOIA rule, which received 65,000+ comments: https://unredacted.com/2019/03/07/forecast-for-sunshine-week-proposed-interior-dept-foia-rules-show-agencies-still-eager-to-weaken-foia-and-congress-eager-to-prevent-it-frinformsum-3-7-2019/ …
Is this consistent with rules from @TheJusticeDept. 
@FOIAPost: "will be engaging with them" (Not an answer)
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Meadows: we need to "streamline the process." Too many people in the chain of approving documents. @RepMarkMeadows asks @FOIAPost to come up with suggestions to improve & report back. #SunshineWeek #FOIA
author: digiphile

text: Now @RepMarkMeadows says FOIA is a bipartisan issue. But hasn't tweeted about #SunshineWeek, as far as I can tell, added his name to oversight letters, or engaged in oversight for the past 2 years: https://sunlightfoundation.com/2017/02/02/what-we-told-congress-about-oversight-ethics-and-open-government/ … #opengov
author: digiphile

text: @johnwonderlich @rachelkbergman, call your office #sunshineweek #FOIA
author: digiphile

text:
Oh: @RepPressley also cites @SunWebIntegrity's report on @TheJusticeDept removed resources for victims of domestic violence. Were you aware?
@FOIAPost Director: No, I was not. 
Important to provide helpful info?
DoJ: definitely important for disclosures to be there
#SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text:
Oh, HAI: @RepPressley just quoted the @SunWebIntegrity report on @CMSgov removing info, & @HHSgov scrubbing info. (cc @SunFoundaiton) She asked if you're aware?
@FOIApost: would refer you to HHS. Encourage agencies to disclose.
author: digiphile

text: No prepared statement online for Tim Epp, acting director of the National #FOIA Office at @EPA. Under @ScottPruittOK (his gov't account is gone) the agency has been accused of slowing requests: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2018/06/11/house-democrat-accuses-scott-pruitt-of-delaying-public-records-requests-by-answering-obama-era-ones-first/ … #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Or that requestors don't know http://FOIA.gov  exists? Or trust it? Or prefer a third party system like @MuckRock? If the "national FOIA portal" had been made a platform at launch, with open API, I think we'd see massive use. https://sunlightfoundation.com/2016/11/02/connecting-freedom-of-information-to-open-data-how-to-build-a-better-foia-gov/ … #SunshineWeek #opengov
author: digiphile

text: There’s a lot of open seats at today’s #FOIA hearing during #SunshineWeek. But @depaoc @RepPressley are here, up front. #opengov
author: digiphile

text: Circumstances of unprecedented requests & lawsuit have led to a environment where professionals incapable of serving FOIA community, say @Interior DCFO. That's why @SecretaryZinke issued an order, she tells Congress: https://www.npr.org/2019/02/17/694466402/interior-dept-s-push-to-limit-public-records-requests-draws-criticism … #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Director of @FOIAPost Pustay is now giving a prepared statement. She says http://FOIA.gov  has received 1 million page views & 9000+ #FOIA requests have been made through it. She notes @TheJusticeDept & @OMBpress issued guidance on interoperability: https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/M-19-10.pdf …
author: digiphile

text: Rep @Jim_Jordan calls out @AmericanOversight & @AREvers by name, saying they're being paid by the @TomSteyer's of the world" to "harass the administration." I'd be curious to hear Jordan describe how @JudicialWatch used FOIA during the Obama administration
author: digiphile

text: Oversight of FOIA should always be bipartisan, says @RepCummings, noting a letter he, @johncornyn @SenatorLeahy @ChuckGrassley sent @interior: https://oversight.house.gov/sites/democrats.oversight.house.gov/files/2019-03-05.EEC%20Leahy%20Grassley%20Cornyn%20to%20Bernhardt-DOI%20re%20FOIA_0.pdf … What’s notable: @Jim_Jordan wasn’t on it. He’s speaking now, extolling transparency as the lifeblood of democracy
author: digiphile

text: "The Trump Administration should be operating with a presumption of openness—as the law now requires—rather than maligning #FOIA requesters who are seeking the truth"-@RepCummings. Some context from #SunshineWeek so far:
author: digiphile

text: And we're off. @RepCummings is delivering this opening statement: https://oversight.house.gov/sites/democrats.oversight.house.gov/files/EEC%20Opening%20Statement%20FOIA%20Hearing%20--%20PRESS%20VERSION%20%28DR%29.pdf … In it, he calls Panuccio's comments at "deeply troubling," @TheJusticeDept "This sounds like DOJ is framing requests for information as obstructions." #sunshineweek #FOIA
author: digiphile

text:
After a delay, today's Oversight Hearing on #FOIA & #opengov  is about to begin: https://oversight.house.gov/legislation/hearings/foia-examining-transparency-under-the-trump-administration …
The livestream is, well, live:
author: digiphile

text: "To reduce FOIA delays & the over-redaction of documents, Congress must  develop a mechanism to force agencies to actually comply with the  Freedom of Information Act, a law that underpins our commitment to #opengov"- @NSANate https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2019/03/13/how-ensure-we-have-more-open-accountable-government/ … #sunshineweek
author: digiphile

text: Delayed! Shall I send you a “still interested” tweet?
author: digiphile

text: While I’m glad there’s a #SunshineWeek hearing on FOIA & #opengov (unlike @senjudiciary, @LindseyGrahamSC) I’m disappointed that @oversightdems did not empanel a second set of witnesses from the requestor & watchdog community. Journalists know exactly how [] bad FOIA is.
author: digiphile

text: The fact that sanctions for violating sunshine laws are almost never applied at any level of government might shed some sunlight on why the state of compliance with public records laws not just in the US government, but around the USA. https://e-pluribusunum.org/2019/03/12/us-government-officials-and-congressmen-praise-open-government-during-sunshine-week-in-dc/ … #SunshineWeek #FOIA
author: digiphile

text: In our democracy, @TheJusticeDept belongs to the public, not any president, like the rest of our government. It’s shameful that any @potus would seek to undermine the DoJ by calling it “broken” or “corrupt,” much less one being investigated. He’s nervous: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/12/us/politics/mueller-report-trump-democrats.html …
author: digiphile

text: Being @verified only means that @Twitter confirmed it’s really them, or at least that the account is controlled by them (many politicians or celebrities employ staff or ghost tweeters.) It doesn’t mean info shared by the account is verified. Twitter hasn’t prioritized fixing it.
author: digiphile

text: Good morning from DC! I savored a morning walk to Rayburn, past @librarycongress & @uscapitol to this morning’s #SunshineWeek hearing on FOIA & transparency:   https://e-pluribusunum.org/2019/03/12/us-government-officials-and-congressmen-praise-open-government-during-sunshine-week-in-dc/ … Apropos of the current climate for #OpenGov, it was both sunny & chilly.
author: digiphile

text: Good call
author: digiphile

text:
Making FOIA requests & lawsuits.
Investigative journalism.
Filing ethics complaints.
Writing & passing bills. 
Not investing capacity any more in a voluntary multi/stakeholder initiative after an administration regressed on previous #opengov commitments.

and this is crazy

Asynchronous polarization around science, nationalism, & delegitimization of journalism by a @potus = epistemic crisis, not just a different administration: https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/11/2/16588964/america-epistemic-crisis … #sunshineweek

text: At #SunshineandScience, @AnnElizabeth18 described standing outside the door of @epa going over open meeting laws with government lawyers, despite access concerns, & finally getting in. The meetings the next day were closed the next day. #opengov in the Trump era. #SunshineWeek
author: digiphile

text: Sociologist & former accountability specialist at @UNDP says there’s naïveté at #SunshineandScience. Panel of journalists isn’t grappling with fundamental regime change in culture & attitude towards the public’s right to know & culture in this administration. Lots of public anger
author: digiphile

text:

Target rich environment: https://trumpconflicts.sunlightfoundation.com/  In Trump Town: https://trumpconflicts.sunlightfoundation.com/ 
#SunshineAndScience

text:
Thanks. That's apt: For some reason, Silberberg is bent on calling lobbyists using digital advertising tools as "ops" in "warfare" but it strikes me as somewhat dangerous hype.

author: digiphile

text: In a new essay, @ipolitico explores how building data protection regimes can counter disinformation:  https://defusingdis.info/2019/03/11/how-building-data-protection-regimes-can-counter-disinformation/ … This is an important angle to the robust conversation going on these issues, with a privacy angle.
author: digiphile

text: Lobbying isn't warfare, even if it uses a tactic similar to one deployed by the military in conflicts. That's the fundamental disconnect here.
author: digiphile

text:
I mean, there's a lot of lobbying going on. It's going digital. But I think you're being a bit irresponsible to call that warfare.

No one has committed an act of war because they target POTUS or his staff. And lobbying civilians isn't "warfare," either.
author: digiphile

text: Seems to me that civilian firms are trying to lobby a public official using geofenced digital advertising, which is a similar approach to tactic used by intelligence officers when they target specific populations in counter-intelligence operations in conflict zones.

text:

My Takeaway: disininformation, in the form of propaganda by nation states or their proxies, may need to be fought as information warfare. But misinformation may be better treated as a public mental health problem.

text:

text: All local media is not doomed; public radio & local TV outlets will endure. text: I remember that, from when you first published it. And yet, here we still are. The editors haven't adjusted. They're publishing deeply reported stories that lay out the bones of this state of affairs but don't deliver a clear, takeaway for the reader. Is it an access limitation?
author: digiphile

text: I agree with the latter part of that assessment. That it's true of both outlets gives me pause about the editing. The takeaway from both is that the POTUS isn't capable of this role, & that the bureaucracies are warping briefings & layers of policymaking to somehow adapt.
author: digiphile

text:
I hoped grouping descriptors together in a tweet would reveal those bones.
Both stories were missing a kicker quote from a former NSA or defense secretary to contextualize how abnormal the situation is & warn of the risks that flow from it. The reporters didn't (couldn't?) say it

text:
2019: A @WhiteHouse @PressSec issued an official statement claiming that @TheDemocrats have a "radical agenda" of "killing babies after they're born." 

At long last, @SHSanders45, have you left no common decency?
author: digiphile

text: But honestly, maybe we should go back to the beginning, & let the fault rest with you? The problems I see stemming from the collapse are founded on evidence, & are likely to grow worse as more papers fold without replacement, not based on some golden glow of civic virtue past.
author: digiphile

text:
I agree. Diversification is key. Memberships. Subsidies. Events. Sponsorships. Individuals. Charities & foundations. Investments. 3 mixes: https://twitter.com/digiphile/status/1091018434387890177 …
I won't speak for anyone else, but I'm worried about corruption, polarization, & a void of info about local govt.
author: digiphile

text: Times have changed, for all the factors you highlight. Wishes won't change that, any more than thoughts & prayers elsewhere. But the papers played a role key role in communities, which is my point. Bergstein proposes a means subsidizing that function. There are others.
author: digiphile

text: If you see a fork in the code, take it.
author: digiphile

text: I dislike online-only polls with a sample size of 4214, but take it for what it is: 60% of those surveyed believe reporters get paid by their sources sometimes, and they don't. Full stop. Claiming otherwise resembles propaganda, not constructive criticism of ethical standards.
author: digiphile

text: From what I can tell, he cites the same study I did, but not the one on polarization. I'm not particularly concerned about whether you want to be performative or are worked up. I care about the evidence regarding the impact of their absence.
author: digiphile

text:
Churnalism is lame.
Some publishers are less ethical than others.
But that poll isn’t talking about better placement.
It’s showing a lot of people think sources pay reporters. And that’s just not true. Right?
author: digiphile

text:
Then …don’t! It’s not just sentimental, though. There is already a direct impact on our politics & our checkbooks: https://twitter.com/digiphile/status/1091019288432046081?s=21 …
The hedge funds & corporations made their beds, but I care about that function, & see a yawning need to replace it in cities & states.
author: digiphile

text: He’s @comey on here
author: digiphile

text: Boston & Cambridge would like to have a word.
author: digiphile

text: The why are you putting journalists in quotes? Or suggesting that sources pay reporters?
author: digiphile

text:
Dear @FOIAPost:
The #OpenGov Data Act is law.
Please stop disclosing annual FOIA data in a PDF during #SunshineWeek.
Please share a narrative as HTML on your website & link to a .csv of #opendata. Please ask @18F @USDS to help you: https://project-open-data.cio.gov/  #opengov
author: digiphile

text:
Everyone doesn’t know that, because it’s not factual. There may be exceptions, but I’ve never seen it in my experiences. 
When you put “journalists” in quotes, it’s a tell that you aren’t coming to this in good faith, nor have respect for the profession I worked in for a decade.
author: digiphile

~62 million people voted for him, out of 200 million or so registered voters. 
That's 31%.

That's 24%.
Or am I missing something?

Every American has the right to question how our tax dollars are spent or the alliances our federal government makes, from Turkey to Saudi Arabia to Israel:
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/04/us/politics/aipac-congress-democrats.html …
What is "unacceptable" is when a Member of Congress tells the public that dissent isn't acceptable.
author: digiphile

text: Investing in relationships in a city or community using social media & email over time enables governments & organizations to build up trust, so that when crises do occur, they have a bank of good faith to draw against. Opacity & silence erodes trust, & leaves information voids.
author: digiphile

@elatable? @SundarPichai?

text: Transparency isn't enough for institutional change. When weak governance systems that failed to address past abuses or incompetence don't take immediate, open steps to implement recommendations & hold leadership accountable, they undermine trust & capacity to achieve a mission.
author: digiphile

text: After half an hour, this tweet was deleted (should show up on @ProPublica's archive:  https://projects.propublica.org/politwoops/user/POTUS … eventually) & then replaced with one with the correct handle for the governor. No transparency about the error nor retraction, but that's nothing new.
author: digiphile

text: Our kindergarten presented their #BlackHistoryMonth projects today. It cute, insightful, poignant & inspiring to hear these little people share who they’d learned about and how each had contributed to making our union stronger, smarter, joyous, and just. https://nmaahc.si.edu/
author: digiphile

text:

Disaster response shouldn’t be predicated on politics.

text: The likelihood of conviction in the Senate should not be the bar for the House impeaching a POTUS. The cost of not impeaching Trump should be given more weight in our politics, given his manifest unfitness for office, but @SpeakerPelosi will wait for Mueller’s report to Congress.
author: digiphile

text: Her journalism is subject to critique, as is everyone’s, but she’s reported a ton of stories that have informed the public, Congress & the courts. Unless you know her personally, it’s both disrespectful & diminutive to use her first name.
author: digiphile

text:
Conversely, *not* impeaching a POTUS who has obstructed justice, lied to the public (including about national security), committed crimes, & violated the Constitution's anti-corruption clauses would also be "a trauma to the country."

I'd posit, in fact, that it already has been.
author: digiphile

text: Since you ask, I have no non-public knowledge to share with you (or others) on that particular question. Unless the SCO's report reveals acts beyond which those which have been disclosed, POTUS' record of corruption, obstruction & maladministration in office appear insufficient.
author: digiphile

text: That's both fair and generous.
author: digiphile

text: I appreciate your response, the caveat, & the reference, if not the characterization of the comment. I shared your reporting last Thursday, as I have for many years: https://twitter.com/search?f=tweets&vertical=default&q=from%3Adigiphile%20maggienyt&src=typd …

digiphile

While he's in office, many positive changes will come from Congress: https://e-pluribusunum.org/2019/01/15/president-trump-signs-historic-open-government-data-bill-into-law/ … (After he's left in office, more fundamental reforms are likely, though I expect how the how he leaves will have a bearing on scope & timing.) Agree on need to learn & tell stories.

text:
No. (I asked since you questioned what my point was.) 

I've spent a decade in DC praising good work when & where it merits it, & criticizing where a given institution falls short. I've tried hard to be fair, informed, accurate, & reasonable. I could do better.
author: digiphile

text: Do you think the agencies or their leadership shouldn't be criticized because of what they've been able to do, "despite" the circumstances?

text:

Conservatism has meant support for institutions, free enterprise, private ownership, "small government," the rule of law, & civic nationalism

text:

The 115th protected him. The 116th seems to be waiting for the special counsel report.

text: This was a challenge while I was at @SunFoundation. When a POTUS is an amoral fabulist who abuses his powers, debases his office, degrades public discourse, & erodes democracy, reporting that he’s done so (much less opposing it) angers partisans, who tell that’s not nonpartisan.
author: digiphile

text:
It is not partisan to report @realDonaldTrump lies.
It IS partisan to claim that he doesn’t.
Or that he isn’t corrupt, or dismiss a history of racism, misogyny, or fraud. Denying his record is not tenable for any journalist, watchdog, or politician who wishes to remain credible.
author: digiphile

text:

text:

This @WhiteHouse signed a bill repealing a key #anticorruption rule at the start of @realDonaldTrump’s team:
https://e-pluribusunum.org/2019/02/26/open-government-partnership-irm-finds-backsliding-in-the-usa/ …
author: digiphile

text: I’ll let the watchdogs can speak for themselves. When we had an administration that held aligned values on human rights, press freedom, the public’s right to know, ethics & corruption, the work of advocates had a different context & set of partners who could deal in good faith.
author: digiphile

text: Thanks to @EvanMcMullin @mindyfinn & the @StandUpFdn team for hosting a collaborative, participatory, & inspiring  #NationalSummitForDemocracy. I left reminded that more connects Americans than divides us, although we have a LOT of work to do to heal divisions across our union.
author: digiphile

text:
Thank you for your service & reflections on open government, part, present & future, @corizarek & @mbgoodman.  https://medium.com/@corizarek/the-future-of-u-s-open-government-rests-with-we-the-people-and-it-s-time-to-step-up-eddbfe59c509 …
I don’t think civil society stopped being interested in #opengov. I think watchdogs stopped viewing @opengovpart as an effective lever in the US.
author: digiphile

text: Yep. It’s the frame that replaces “Gov 2.0,” which was also adopted by big tent. It has primarily been pushed & propagated by foundations, most notably Omidyar & CfA : https://www.omidyar.com/spotlight/what-can-civic-tech-learn-social-movements … & used ambiguously by s small number of trade publications & writers (like, ahem, me)

text:
We do need them to act.
To do otherwise is to cede how democracy works to tech companies.
We need them to be smarter, to legislate better, not from positions of ignorance. 
That means increasing their capacity to understand tech:

text: Useful to think about what challenges to democracy are driven or exacerbated by tech, & what changes platforms could make, & what problems can’t be fixed short of constitutional reform. If they do decide to debunk, don't privilege his lies. Lead with facts.

What to do?

The globe is warming due to human activity.

text:
And the people refreshed and prayed
To the smartphone gods they made
And my inbox flashed out its warning
In the words that it was forming
And the screen said, "The words of the spammers
Are written on the Facebook walls
And server firewalls"
And whispered in the sounds of email.
author: digiphile

text:
"Fools" said I, "You do not know
Email like a cancer grows
DM me so I might teach you
Text my phone so I might reach you”
But my words like silent raindrops fell
And echoed in the bowels of email
author: digiphile

text:
And in the naked light I saw
Ten thousand emails, maybe more
People writing without speaking
People reading without listening
People sending spam that servers never shared
No one dared
Disturb the sound of email
author: digiphile

text:
In restless dreams I browsed alone
Narrow screens of Apple phones
'Neath the halo of a desk lamp
I moved my fingers as they were cold and cramped
When my eyes were stabbed by the flash of a laptop light
That split the night
And heard the sound of email
author: digiphile

Worse still: the evidence points to that being intentional. Malign neglect is a best case. This looks like a feature, not a bug, of the 115th Congress & this @WhiteHouse’s neglect of our institutions.
author: digiphile

text: @CoryBooker, call your office
author: digiphile

text: You can learn more about @USAID’s programs here: https://www.usaid.gov/democracy  & @StateDRL’s programs here: https://www.state.gov/j/drl/p/
author: digiphile

text:
What priority do you place on promoting democracy, human rights, & press freedom? Who is running @StateDRL?
What about transparency, accountability, & good governance?
author: digiphile
